title: Allow forking task runners to terminate and pickup their tasks.
body:
- Communication between MM and peon is accomplished via file system stuff. (adding and deleting files)
- Force killing a peon is only available on systems which understand the `kill` command with -15 and -9 as options
- Currently does not follow prior behavior. There is no option to force tasks to shutdown on MM exit
- Adds ShutdownResource which adds an endpoint which shuts down the service (currently only used by peon)
- Add unit tests for ForkingTaskRunner. These take a while to run because they spawn up JVMs.

This allows upgrading the middle manager without killing peons.

Requires https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1524

title: Azure Blob Store support for Firehose and Indexing Service Logs
body:
This builds upon the existing azure extension, adding support for Azure's Blob Store as a Firehose and target for Indexing Service logs. The functionality is nearly identical to the S3 implementations. Most of the code was based off of that, simply using the Azure SDK instead.

For the firehose, I chose a uri scheme like `azureblobstore://container/path/to/your/file.json` which might seem weird considering the "endpoint" is actually `https://myaccount.blob.core.windows.net/container/path/to/your/file.json` 

I opted for a uri like this because the current azure extension configures settings like a storage account, access key and schema (http/https) globally. I believe using the "official" URI would give the illusion of being able to use any storage account, which would lead to a bad user experience.

I considered a couple of other solutions like having to specify a storage account and key for each usage (ex. separate properties for the firehose account and indexing service account), but I didn't like that either as the current property for setting an account implies that it's global and I didn't want to introduce breaking changes in the azure extension. Having one that sounded global, but having it only apply to the deep storage is also a bad user experience.

If anyone has any other ideas for this I'd be happy to discuss. Otherwise, merge at will.

title: integration-tests: add ability to get configuration information from a file
body:
This is the first of what I hope will be a short series of PRs that will make some  generalizations and enhancements to the way things work in integration-tests. The goal is that we (and other groups) can run the tests unchanged out of the community source, and be able to contribute tests more easily.
For this first one, I'm proposing adding an alternate configuration class to the existing class DockerConfigProvider.

We need this because we run integration tests using other configurations than a single-host druid cluster using docker with the hardcoded port numbers present in DockerConfigProvider.java.  We also are writing tests that need configuration information other than druid host and port numbers.

I added a new implementation ConfigFileConfigProvider of  IntegrationTestingConfigProvider.  It is used if druid.test.config.type is "configFile" rather then the default value of "docker", and it reads configuration information from the file specified by druid.test.config.configFile.

The first piece of new configuration information we need is the zookeeper address, because we're working on tests that use it. I added a function get ZookeeperHost() to IntegrationTestingConfigProvider and its implementations.

I added to pom.xml a profile int-tests-config-file that doesn't start docker and sets the values of druid.test.config.type (to configFile) and druid.test.config.configFile (to a value from the environment).

I tested by running ITRealtimeIndexerTaskTest two ways:
. the "docker" way (but without docker):
  . commented out the setup and shutdown of docker in the .sh files
  . set the environment variable DOCKER_IP to a virtual machinewhere I have a single-host druid system running
  . changed the hard-coded port IDs in DockerConfigProvider 
  . mvn verify -P integration-tests -Dit.test=ITIndexerTest
. the "config file" way:
  . export CONFIG_FILE=properties.json
  . mvn verify -P int-tests-config-file -Dit.test=ITRealtimeIndexTaskTest

title: fix groupBy caching to work with renamed aggregators
body:
Issue - while storing results in cache we store the event map which
contains aggregator names mapped to values. Now when someone fire same
query after renaming aggs, the cache key will be same but the event
will contain metric values mapped to older names which leads to wrong
results.

Fix - modify cache to not store raw event but the actual list of values
only.

title: say explicitly that local firehose searches dirs recursively for files
body:
I'd like to change the description of the local firehose to make it more clear that the search of the directory specified by baseDir is done recursively through subdirectories.  I guess I should have realized that from the use of "baseDir" itself, but as an old Unix user I'm not used to commands being done recursively unless I specifically say so (I know, git -add ...).  

If we make it more clear that the search is recursive, it might save someone from accidentally ingesting data that they didn't intend.

I think it would also be nice to change the "Searching for" log message in the task log to say that it's searching "in and beneath" the directory, because to someone totally literal like me, searching "in" a directory means  searching only in that directory.  If we add a log message showing what files are being used, it could help with diagnosing the problem if an ingestion task didn't do what was expected because of using files that weren't intended to be used.

(I'm assuming here that the recursion was intentional.)

title: JobHelper.ensurePaths will set job properties from config (tuningConfâ¦
body:
Fix for https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/1463

JobHelper.ensurePaths will set job properties from config (tuningConfig.jobProperties) before adding input paths to the config.
    Adding input paths will create Path and FileSystem instances which may depend on the values in the job config.
    This allows all properties to be set from the spec file, avoiding having to directly edit cluster xml files.

```
IndexGeneratorJob.run adds job properties before adding input paths (adding input paths may depend on having job properies set)

JobHelperTest confirms that JobHelper.ensurePaths adds job properties
```

title: kafka 8 simple consumer firehose
body:
This feature introduces a simple consumer implementation for realtime firehose. It keeps track of current offset metadata by storing it in metadata.drd with smooshed files, and will be able to recover the previous offset position after restart.
On restart, it take down the offset from the sequentially "last" valid persisted file, and rename all incomplete persist directory to a path for corrupted data. e.g. there are sub dirs /1, /2, /3, ..../8 under directory mydatasource/20150630T10:00:00-11:00:00/, and /7 doesn't contain meta.smoosh, RealtimePlumber will rename both /7 and /8 to corrupted/mydatasource/20150630T10:00:00-11:00:00/\* and use offset from /6 as starting point.
When indexing, it follows the logic:
1. Call start()
2. Read currRow()
3. Call advance()
4. If index should be committed: commit()
5. GOTO 2
Note it will only advance when current row is successfully processed, which means saving the end offset of current message.
@cheddar 

Google Group reference:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/druid-development/9HB9hCcqvuI

title: Realtime Index Task test
body:
Test Realtime Index Task by adding it to the TaskQueue- 
- Expect it to run the task
- Expect task to connect to firehose and initialize plumber
- Announce a Sink for the events
- Ingest all the events from firehose
- Persist and merge all the events
- Publish and push the segment
- Tasks wait for hand off condition to happen as simulation of historical announcing the published segment is not done

title: minor documentation fixes in Tasks.md, index.md, indexing-service.md
body:
In misc/Tasks.md, the specification for a realtime indexing task includes this line:
      "basePersistDirectory": "\/tmp\/realtime\/basePersist"
But, realtime indexing tasks do not use this for the location of the persist directory; they all seem to use /tmp/druid/persistent.  I'm suggesting that the line be removed.

In Configuration/index.md, I fixed a sentence that had broken grammar, I hope giving it the correct meaning.

In Configuration/indexing-service.md, it shows two endpoints using COORDINATOR_IP.  These seem like they should be OVERLORD_IP.  If I use the coordinator ip I get a Not Found error.

title: Fix bad distribution of cache keys across cache nodes
body:
With the existing hash function some nodes could end up with 3 times the
number of keys as others. The following changes improve that to roughly
less than 5% differences across nodes (when using 5 nodes).
- switch from fnv-1a to murmur3_128 hash
- increase repetitions for ketama algorithm
- test to analyze distribution

Also updates spymemcached for recent bugfixes

title: Druid Coordinator test
body:
When a coordinator runs -
- It should start leader election and become leader
- It should look for segments and historical DruidServer
- It should go through rules and try to assign segments to historical DruidServer
  As of now only the above mentioned coordinator activities are tested.

repo.name: druid
repo.description: Apache Druid: a high performance real-time analytics database.

title: Make AbstractHttpClientProvider contents lazily instantiated
body:
Currently AbstractHttpClientProvider instantiates its fields eagerly, which could become problematic when extension modules tries to bind everything they need and expect the druid process to instantiate what they actually do need. Guice tries to fail-fast and verifies that all bindings exist before it does anything, which is a problem because the extension bind some objects that don't necessarily have all of their dependencies bound in all processes.(Referred to #243)

This PR lazily instantiated some fields so that they are created when they are actually needed.

repo.name: druid
repo.description: Apache Druid: a high performance real-time analytics database.

title: Fix duplicate extension loading issue described in #1016
body:
This patch aims to fix issue #1016  

Currently if we put something in `druid.extensions.coordinates`, the local module that was previsouly loaded will be accidentally loaded again. The reason is that the return value of the second `ServiceLoader.load(clazz, loader)` in the original code still contains previously loaded module. Since `Set<T> retVal` is not doing its job by filtering out loaded modules, previously loaded module will be added again. If that module happens to create Guice bindings, duplicate binding errors will occur.

This patch adds a HashSet that keeps track the module names that have already been loaded.

I also rearranged the order in which the extensions are loaded. Extensions explicitly specified in `druid.extensions.coordinates` have a higher priority.

title: Separate overwrite of Guice modules into 2 steps and minor style fix
body: Currently during initialization, cliModules and extension modules are loaded at the same level, which makes extension modules not able to overwrite cliModules(For example, the JettyHttpClientModule installed in CliRouter can't be overwritten by our extension module). This PR separates the overwrite step in Initialization.java into two steps so that extension module can overwrite bindings in cliModule.

title: Check lower bound of replicant values for rules
body: Do not allow replicant values less than 0. In case of negative replicant value, the coordinator will try to remove more replicas of segment than the actual number of replicas and can start throwing warning "Wtf, holder was null? I have no servers serving [%s]?", segment.getIdentifier()"

title: fix behaviour of middlemanagers around ZK disconnects , fixes #709
body:
At present there are multiple places from which the task status can get deleted which leads to issues where the state of middle manager and overlord gets out of sync when either the middle manager is rebooted. Also the state changes can be lost during leadership changes. 

This PR makes the overlord to be the _only_ thing that deletes the status, and for it to _not_ be an ephemeral node. 
The changes include - 
1) change task status _not_ to be ephemeral nodes 
2) If a middlemanager is restarted it updates the task status for tasks running from previous run to FAILED. 
3) RemoteTaskRunner now waits for configurable grace period before failing a task when the worker is temporarily disconnected from ZK. 
4) RemoteTaskRunner ensures proper cleanup of task status nodes.

title: More benchmarks for data compression
body:
Add more benchmarks for data compression for both single valued and multi valued columns.
1) Add benchmark tests for single valued column compression
2) instead of accessing each value in a column, define filterSkip variable in the jmh tests defines a filter where the test reads every nth row in a column 

Benchmark Results with random reads 
jdk 1.7.0_80 on amazon ec2 m3.xlarge instance - 
https://gist.github.com/nishantmonu51/3eb4fe523edfd242ee86
with jdk8 1.8.0_45 
https://gist.github.com/nishantmonu51/158db259ae2e6c23e9a5

The results shows that when filter accesses a fairly large subset of rows, the overall compression overheads are amortised over the rows being accessed. 
In case the  filter reads only a few rows the compression overheads are noticeable. 
Also these overheads are applicable to all the compressed column types (Single Valued - Long/Int and Multi Valued)

title: Converter to use TaskMerger not TaskMaker
body:
Finally was able to do some validation to make sure of some unknowns:
- Both Merger and Maker pass validation for data integrity
- The Maker version also takes 6 times as long to run compared to Merger.
- Resultant segment sizes were comparable but not equal.

So this reduces the execution time by ~80%

This depends on PRs
- ~~https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1351~~
- ~~https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1403~~

title: Add schema check for overlap between dimension and metric names
body:
Druid will evaluate the schema in the following order:

1) Any column listed in the list of dimensions is treated as a dimension
2) Any column listed in the list of dimension exclusions is excluded as a dimension
3) Timestamp and required fields by metrics are excluded by default
4) If a metric is also listed as a dimension, the metric must have a different name than the dimension name.
